the reduction of light response region of the samples with thinner structure, which is unfavorable for the photocatalytic reaction. Photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 is a complicated multistep reaction.The catalytic performance is correlated to a number of factors such as light response region, photoinduced electron-hole pair separation efficiency, charge carrier migration ability, redox ability of the CB and VB of a catalyst.The photocatalytic reduction performance of the catalysts prepared in this work

the reduction potential of all the samples are more negative than the reduction potential of the CO 2 derived products listed in Fig. 9, and the oxidative potential of all the catalysts are more positive than the oxidative potential of H 2 O (0.82 V).Hence, all the samples are able to convert CO 2 to the product listed in Fig. 9 with H 2 O in the absence of any sacrificial agent.However, the bandgap width increases with decreasing thickness from CN-1 to CN-4, indicating the reduction of light response

which was placed in the quartz reactor containing 0.5 mL H 2 O. Subsequently, the reaction system was purged with CO 2 thoroughly to remove the air in the reactor.Then the reaction system was subjected to irradiation under simulated sunlight (Xenon lamp, 300 W) for 4 h.The reaction sample was collected every 1 h from the reaction system and analyzed by a chromatography (GC5890, Nanjing kejie instrument) equipped with flame ionization detector (FID) detector and methanation instrument.

inside to the surface of the catalyst, and remarkably lowers the recombination possibility of electrons and holes.The effective electronhole pairs separation, fast charge carrier migration speed and reduced transport pathway of CN-4 all favor the improvement of photocatalytic catalytic activity. In addition to the charge carrier separation and migration efficiency, the conduction band (CB) and valance band (VB) position, that is redox potential, also play a critical role in the photocatalytic reactions.XPS
